I am come here to die! — the battle's yell</br>Hath fainted into stillness; — and I hail</br>Nature's bland voice again — the mellow swell</br>Of the far billow, which the moon-beam pale</br>Hath kiss'd into repose: — the evening gale,</br>Rich with the spoil of violets, seems to creep</br>On the charmed ear so softly musical,</br>As it would bid the wretched cease to weep,</br>And o'er the victor's rage fling the sweet spell of sleep.

Yes — let him sleep — and wake to toil again!</br>Yet be there other sleepers, round whose bed</br>The balmy tears of Eve are wept in vain,—</br>And morn will smile — it cannot wake the dead.</br>Spirits of song! — my brethren! — are ye fled?—</br>Ye have not lived to rue a tyrant's hate,—</br>To see your shrines — your dwellings ravished;—</br>I do not — dare not mourn your glorious fate;—</br>But feel that ye are gone — and I am desolate.

My lonely lyre! — my hand is on thy string—</br>It is the last — last time — my childhood's toy—</br>Fond solace of my youth, wilt thou not bring</br>To my last hour one parting note of joy?—</br>I do remember, when a wayward boy,</br>How I would woo thee, till my soul caught fire,</br>And glowed — and maddened in the sweet employ—</br>How I would far from human eye retire,</br>To talk in solitude with thee, — my lonely lyre!

Then, Mona!  'mid thy forest grandeur nursed,</br>I drank the rapture of thy Druid's strain;—</br>Then airy forms on fancy's slumber burst,</br>And youth's bright dreams, as beautiful, as vain.</br>Yet not at once that Druid loosed the chain,</br>That bound my soul, — and bade it, madly whirled</br>In fire-wheeled car, Heaven's peerless height attain:</br>But darkly — slowly the dread truth unfurled,—</br>And drew the curtain back, that veils another world.—

Sweet Memory!  touched by thee, enjoyment past</br>A brighter hue — a livelier beauty wears;</br>And thou art wont, in playful mood, to cast</br>The rainbow's lustre o'er a scene of tears:</br>Thus now, beneath thy softened tint, appears</br>The pang — the struggle, when my soul was riven</br>From all of Earth, that soothes — enchants — endears—</br>From human passion's blandishment — and given</br>With all its warmth of zeal, to solitude and heaven.—

The faith, I cherished, was a feeling rife</br>With poesy and grandeur and delight:</br>Oh!  when Belinus woke the world to life,</br>My eager hand would rouse his beacon bright!—</br>My song would chide the lingering gloom of night!—</br>And, as he rose, and, flinging from the sky</br>Round Snowdon's brow his glittering wreath of light,</br>Laughed on the waves, that smil'd responsively,</br>My spirit caught a glow for mortal breast too high.—

And him the storm-god Taranis, whose eye</br>Glares through the clouds in lightning, where the rout</br>Of mingled elements rolls hurrying by—</br>Him have I worshipped, — and his awful shout,</br>That chorus, by his deep voice bellowed out,</br>Was full of joy and melody to me.</br>I loved to hear it leap heaven's vault about;</br>Till Earth took up the song with noisy glee,</br>And pealed from all her hills its fierce antistrophe.

There be some moments to our musing given</br>Full of eternity! — and such were mine;</br>When I could feel this bosom — spark of Heaven—</br>This purer essence of a breath divine</br>Gaze back on what it had been — to its shrine</br>Of other years, or raise, in shadowy files,</br>Visions of future being, till it shine</br>Throned in the splendor of those sunny isles,</br>Where endless pleasures reign, and cloudless beauty smiles.

But such were lonely joys — the festive song,</br>The slow procession, and the solemn rite—</br>The shout, that rung the startled woods among,</br>"Gather the mystic branch, the year's last night</br>Melts into morn!" — these once could wake delight,—</br>'Twas proud to see the Druid throng sweep by,</br>Their white robes glistening in the Moon's young light;</br>Which, struggling through the oak's dark shade on high,</br>Glanced on the scene below of sacred revelry.—

Oft too we tracked the forest's deep abyss,</br>To seek such wilding herb, or summer flower,</br>In whose bright chalice evening's dewy kiss</br>Nursed health or poison: — at this dreadful hour</br>I thank those venomed leaves, whose kindly power</br>Shall free my longing spirit: — once I blessed</br>A charm, that, gathered from a fairer bower,</br>Poured refluent vigour through the purest breast,</br>That e'er for mortal youth love's trembling flame confessed.

Yes I did love her, though that love to me</br>Was all forbidden rapture! — her pale cheek</br>Sunk on my throbbing breast, — and droopingly</br>Bowed her frail form, so delicately weak;</br>I waved the vervain-bough, and strove to speak</br>The potent spell — Oh Heaven! — It died away</br>Her eye's delirious fire — the livid streak,</br>That stained her brow; and in its stead, a ray</br>Beamed forth, more mildly bright than parting blush of day.

Hence radiant phantom! — vainly beautiful!—</br>Thine eye's blue languor, and thy sun-kist hair</br>Have soothed my soul: — but now — 'tis cramped and dull</br>In the cold desolation of despair.</br>Hence loveliness! — I'll seek in thought the bare</br>And rugged piles, which Genii's strength and skill</br>Toiled, a proud temple to our gods to rear;</br>I'll think of that fierce pang, whose shuddering thrill</br>Froze me, when first I marked the vital stream distill

From human victim's side; — with ruthless aim</br>The priest had dealt the blow — the seer stood nigh,</br>Watching each motion of the quivering frame,—</br>Each strong contortion of the lip and eye.</br>He bade me strike my lyre — unknowing why</br>I tremblingly obeyed: — but — mark! — the while</br>The victim's sunken cheek beamed faint reply</br>To notes, that thus could deadliest throe beguile,—</br>And his pale lip grew still; — and froze into a smile.

These were thy rites, red Hesus! — but to thee</br>There was a gentler sacrifice of song.</br>How, 'mid the feast of shells, I've smiled to see</br>The whirlwind passions of the savage throng</br>Spell-bound by music; — now the war-note strong</br>Yelled, in deep concert to the martial strain,</br>That bounded swellingly my chords' along;—</br>And then I hushed them into tears again,</br>With a low wailing dirge for early valor slain.—

One night — one solemn night — with him, my guide</br>Of early youth — my Druid-friend I sought</br>The solitary shore — the breeze had died;</br>And scarce it's gentle kiss one dimple wrought</br>In Ocean's cheek: — he paused — the moon-beam caught</br>His face upraised to heaven, and, as it shone,</br>Tinged with a paler hue those lines of thought;—</br>He seized my lyre, and woke one deep — deep tone—</br>"Mortal, he cried, attend! — know God is God alone.

"Gaze forth into Creation!  view him there!—</br>His voice is thunder, and his shadow — light!</br>The forms of earth — the glorious gems of air</br>Are symbols of his attributes; — his might</br>Called this fair orb from Chaos and from night;</br>And yet again shall that blue sky be furled,—</br>That page deep stamped with characters so bright</br>Of praise and power, — again, to ruin hurled,</br>Fierce flames shall spread a pall above this smiling world."

Would that dread hour were come! — I could rejoice</br>To see those flames, in Earth's deep bosom pent,</br>Rear the red flag of havoc, and the voice</br>Of the Omnipotent, in thunder sent,</br>Annihilate the universe: — content</br>My soul fair Nature's blackening wreck would scan,—</br>Spring forth into its native element</br>And revel in its liberty — it can</br>Bow to the will of Heaven — but not the yoke of man.

My country!  I have gazed upon thy face—</br>Thy sleeping face — thy moon-light loveliness—</br>Then was such grandeur mingled with such grace,</br>I could scarce weep away the fond excess</br>Of passionate admiration — thy blue dress—</br>Thy beauteous zone of Ocean, — Snowdon's might,</br>Whose rugged sides each varied shade confess</br>Of ebon and of ivory: — at night</br>Say who could look on these, and weep not at the sight?

Yes weep — and love — and worship — so did I:—</br>But now grief, anger, hatred, shame, remorse</br>Have made the fountains of my soul grow dry,—</br>Have frozen the tide of feeling in its course.</br>My country thou art lost! — a tyrant's force</br>Winds his base chain around thy giant hills,—</br>Withers thy sacred oaks, — and, oh!  far worse,</br>Enslaves thy free-born sons, and coldly spills</br>Thy heart's best blood!  'tis well — he is no foe who kills.

We fought for thee, my country; — 'twas the strife</br>Of desperate rage — the struggle of despair—</br>The last wild stroke for liberty and life:—</br>We braved the invader in his fierce career,—</br>Thy Druid daughters with their flowing hair,</br>Poured in mad onset on the foe, and high</br>Raised the shrill shriek, — and tossed the torch in air;—</br>Thy grey rocks, echoing back their thrilling cry,</br>Sent the dread war-note forth — "To death or victory!"—

On — on we rushed; — the Roman's serried file</br>Shrunk, as it marked the coming tempest grow,</br>Then paused with sullen and contemptuous smile,—</br>And calmly stern — determinately slow,</br>Levelled at once the lance's bristling row.—</br>On — on we rushed — what reeked we if to die?</br>My brethren bared their bosom to the foe,</br>Blessing the murderer with their latest sigh,</br>Whose mercy gave but chains — whose death-blow — liberty.

Rejoice, proud Empress of a groaning world!</br>Where battle's crimson tide flows deep and strong,</br>Be thy triumphant eagle's wing unfurled!</br>And, when soft peace glides laughingly along,</br>Thine be the festive dance — the joyous song!</br>I do not curse thee, Rome. — Live, tyrant! — live!—</br>Yet is there One will measure wrong for wrong—</br>The God, — the God of vengeance; — He will give</br>As thou hast given, — for me — I spurn thee, and — forgive.

Ha! — 'twas the shriek of death! — again! — again!</br>What visions to my strengthened eye are given!—</br>A fiery shore — a blood-empurpled main—</br>Through lurid clouds of smoke, in tumult driven,</br>The scythe-armed chariot — helm, and buckler riven:—</br>Yes! — Britain triumphs — Britain's warrior-queen!</br>Rome bites the dust — Right bravely have ye striven,</br>Children of liberty! — the time hath been</br>When bards would hymn your praise — and yet again, I ween,

That time will come: — the veil is half withdrawn—</br>The future's veil of gloom — I see — I see</br>The horizon purpling with thy glory's dawn,</br>My native land! — thy soils shall yet be free—</br>And brave, — but not in vain — thy name shall be</br>The rallying-shout of nations — heard afar</br>In distant lands, and thundered o'er the sea;—</br>Thy blood red standard, victory's beacon-star,</br>Shall stream with meteor flash along the clouds of war.

And then, perchance, this fluttering soul of mine,</br>That thus in music sighs itself away,</br>Again shall prompt some happier bard, to twine</br>Thy fadeless oak-wreath with his rapturous lay—</br>To sing the triumphs of thy brighter day:—</br>Till then, farewell, dark Mona's woody dell!</br>Farewell, thou deep blue sea! — ye mountains grey!</br>Farewell, my lyre! — thy last expiring swell</br>Just echoes — it is past — my lonely lyre, farewell!</br>
